posts.name: Noah
posts.cooked: Hi Cd, I‚Äôm going through some great difficulties at the moment. In the last few days I‚Äôve seen that it‚Äôs possible to use keyboards to pilot robots. I was impressed and determined to do it. So I started my tests by writing a code using a library that receives the keys from my computer and publishes them on the dashboard. However, I saw that this code didn‚Äôt work when I connected the code to Rio. Since then, I‚Äôve been lost as to how to do this. Does anyone know how I can use the keyboards in another way? I also saw that I could download software to simulate a joystick. However, when I talked to other programmers about this, they warned me that this could cause errors in real arenas. If anyone has used something similar, please give me some advice.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Noah01:

In the last few days I‚Äôve seen that it‚Äôs possible to use keyboards to pilot robots.

Can you link in some of the topics / posts you were looking at?

posts.name: Noah
posts.cooked: I see this topic, but I don‚Äôt know python and I don‚Äôt know very well how to use these external codes, the little I know about programming is only for robots within vscode, I don‚Äôt understand much about other concepts. Keyboard and Mouse as a controller... (again) .   So I looked for Java adaptations with a bit of chatgpt and vscode tutorials on youtube

link_counts.title: Keyboard and Mouse as a controller... (again)

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
More detail here is needed. However one issue I am aware of is pygame window needs to be in focus. That means and has to be on top. This is especially important after you click enable on DS as window focus will go to DS . You need to click on pygame window to have your input captured. Otherwise nothing will work.

Also on inst.setServer("127.0.0.1") in that python script you need to change that to your roboRIO IP address.

It would also be helpful if you have your java code available.

posts.name: Noah
posts.cooked: In reality I didn‚Äôt understand how to use pygame, the only thing I developed was a class within my code in vscode that sent to the networktable when my key was pressed, I don‚Äôt have the complete code in git but I‚Äôll send at least the part of the class

posts.name: Noah
posts.cooked: import java.awt.event.KeyEvent; import java.awt.event.KeyListener; import javax.swing.JFrame; public class KeyboardReader extends JFrame implements KeyListener { private boolean spacePressed = false; public KeyboardReader() { this.setFocusable(true); this.setSize(100, 100); this.setVisible(true); this.addKeyListener(this); } public boolean isSpacePressed() { return spacePressed; } @Override public void keyPressed(KeyEvent e) { if (e.getKeyCode() == KeyEvent.VK_SPACE) { spacePressed = true; } } @Override public void keyReleased(KeyEvent e) { if (e.getKeyCode() == KeyEvent.VK_SPACE) { spacePressed = false; } } @Override

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
What your code is trying to do here is capture local keystroke. Unfortunately, roboRIO don‚Äôt have a keyboard attached so this will not work.

my pygame speaks NetworkTables . Keyboard are treated as buttons and mouse movement are treated as analogue input. You need to subscribe to these values and have your actuators react to it.

link_counts.title: What is NetworkTables ‚Äî FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked: yup I can concur that this is right. You can also set up a trigger to bind commands to seeing things in networktables.  our code, which supports keyboard controls, is at GitHub - aesatchien/FRC2429_2025: Python code for FRC 2429's 2025 robot(s) ; it‚Äôs probably less easy to understand than @NathanZhou 's though.  Note that polling all this stuff takes up some loop time.  It did save us a few times at Tidal when the controller disconnected though.

link_counts.title: GitHub - aesatchien/FRC2429_2025: Python code for FRC 2429's 2025 robot(s)

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked:
This is our code for it: RobotCode2025/src/main/python/keyboard_to_nt.py at main ¬∑ Programming-TRIGON/RobotCode2025 ¬∑ GitHub

This code just runs in the background on the computer and publishes all keys to the nt. We use it with this Keyboard Controller class .

Easiest way that we have done it is to use a program called KeyboardSplitter , and it converts a keyboard into an Xbox controller detected by the DS .

In years past, we have used a mechanical numpad as an operator controller by binding the buttons on it to Xbox buttons.

link_counts.title: GitHub - djlastnight/KeyboardSplitterXbox: Creates up to 4 virtual xbox 360 controllers and feeds them via one or more keyboards.

posts.cooked:
Instead of using NetworkTables, we wrote a python script that uses the vjoy library to create a virtual controller, which the robot can then see as raw HID buttons. The window does not need to be focused. This was very robust and performed well at 4 different competitions.

There was also an earlier version of this file that used the vgamepad library to emulate an Xbox 360 controller, but we ran out of buttons.

Latest (vjoy) version: key2joy.py (3.1 KB)

Earlier (vgamepad) version: key2joy.py (3.1 KB)

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked:
We did something similar with vgamepad to use a Stream Deck ( python api ) as an operator button board. Worked great.

We got around the limited button issue by using the axes as bit fields; you can get 8 extra ‚Äúbuttons‚Äù per trigger (2) and 16 per joystick axis (4) like this, for a total of 80 extra buttons.
